captions.text: Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday.

So when Sarah and I moved to New York, in
2005, we hired some people off Craigslist

to help us move our furniture into our new
apartment; including a guy from, I think,

Eastern Europe, and when I asked him why he'd
moved to the United States he said "In New

York anyone who can work can work", which
is like the best one sentence summary of an

efficient labor market I've ever heard. Anyway
when he asked what I did I told him that my

first novel "Looking for Alaska" had come
out recently; and he said "Oh, I wanna work

in publishing"; and I was thinking, you know
"Yeah, book publishing's a good star to hitch

your wagon to" and then we went back to moving
boxes.

Flash forward about a year. I'm at a big publishing
conference and a guy wearing a suit walks

up to me and says "Hey, I moved you into your
apartment, Looking for Alaska!" and it was

the guy from Craigslist and sure enough he
was working in international sales for a huge
publishing company.

And that's the American Dream, right? People
come to our fair shores because here anyone

who can work can work. Our national self-understanding
is supported by anecdotes like this: from

the Craigslist furniture mover; to the impoverished
child turned steel magnate Andrew Carnegie,

or Car-NAY-gee depending on how pretentious
you are. But Hank, the actual data is somewhat
less dreamy.

Quick aside to all of you saying that I should
say "data are" because "data" is a plural
noun... come on.

Right but anyway 42% of American men raised
in the bottom 20% of incomes stay there. In

the UK that number is 30%; in Denmark, it's
25%. In fact by almost any measure, whether

you are born rich or poor in the United States
is a better indicator of whether you will

end up rich or poor than it is in Canada or
Europe or any country in the developed world.

When we talk about socioeconomic mobility
and equality of opportunity in the 21st century,

we're not really talking about the American
Dream. We're talking about the Danish Dream.

Here's another metric that I think is really
interesting: Economic opportunities for women.

In the United States, women make 77 cents
for every dollar that men make in the workforce.

Just to be clear, that's horrifically unjust,
but it's also really economically problematic

because you don't want people to be paid according
to their sex. You want them to be paid according

to their skills and contributions. So in the
US, women make 77 cents for every Dude Dollar.

Canada is actually worse than us but they
have a little bit of a weird economy. But

in Australia it's 83 cents; in the UK it's
84; in Sweden it's 85. And in Slovenia, the

world's most underrated country, women make
97.5 cents for every dollar that men make
in the workforce.

Now Hank, the American Dream remains uniquely
"American" in one sense: we are far more likely

than residents of other countries to believe
that people are rewarded for intelligence

and skill, and we're less likely to believe
that coming from a wealthy family is key to

getting ahead. Unfortunately, like a lot of
dreams, what we're dreaming isn't real.

Now Hank, I want to add that the same regulations
in redistributive tax policies that allow

for better equality of opportunity in the
rest of the world do limit innovation. And

that's definitely part of the reason why hugely
innovative companies like Apple and Twitter

and Google and In-n-Out Burger all started
in the US. But my worry is that systemic inequality

of opportunity will prevent the most promising
future innovators from getting the opportunities

they need to succeed. And I worry that the
US will become progressively less appealing

to the smartest people with the best skills.
I mean, the place where "if you can work,

you can work" won't be the US anymore, it'll
be Denmark or Slovenia.

Like, Hank, if you're a female computer programmer
today and you have both a Slovenian and an

American passport, you're probably still best
off working in the United States. But if current

trends continue, that may not be the case
in a decade. And that's why systemic inequality

of opportunity is bad, not just for Americans
living in poverty, but for all Americans.

By the way shoutout to Slovenian readers of
Krive So Zvezde, I'm basically fluent in Slovenian.

Hank, I also wanted to say thanks for your
video on consent and abuse; it really did

make me proud to be your brother. D'oh my
god what is this, Esther Day? I'll see you
on Friday.

comments.author: Sara Harrison

comments.text:
I would like to further discuss this idea of income inequality. John states 
in this video that women make 77 cents to every dollar that men make in the 
United States--the same statistic that endless democratic politicians have 
reiterated repeatedly. Let me first say, that I am a relatively liberal 
thinking person and absolutely think that women should be paid equally to 
men. However, this statistic that is used so frequently is just skewed. 
Women make less money because by in large, they often go into careers that 
are associated with lower pay, despite being extremely important 
careers...social work, nursing, education, etc. Also, on average, women 
work less over the course of a year. Not because they are lazy, but because 
women tend to be more family-oriented (this ultimately results in a lower 
income as well).
The statistic does not imply that women are making 77 cents less for the 
exact same job as a man--thats how politicians spin it, but thats not true 
to the statistic. To provide a personal anecdote, my father was head of a 
local police department, and thus had access to payment records. Female law 
enforcement officers were provided the exact same opportunities as men 
(annual raises, same starting salary, etc.).﻿

comments.author: Bruni

comments.text:
There are many indicators that the wage gap is a myth, especially when it 
comes to saying that equally skilled workers who are women are getting less 
for their work. Here are some reasons as why that is the case: 
1. The data usually take all women and all men earnings in all occupations 
put them all together and divide by the number of women and men working 
regardless of their specific occupation, experience or skills; 
2, women tend to choose less lucrative occupation, like in child care etc. 
All this is made by choice. I personally have witnessed very academically 
talented girls of my age choosing to go to "easier" schools to take care of 
kinder garden children for example despite the fact they had the mental 
capacity and work ethic to get them trough for more challenging (at least 
in academic terms) profession and definitely more lucrative profession than 
they chose. Sure, they finished school sooner then I would finish law 
school but take average earnings of a lawyer and a kinder garden teacher... 
you get the idea.
 It makes up for the much of the difference in overall earnings that men 
make compared to all women; 
3. women tend to put family first more than men. For some reason it is 
considered less valuable than to further your own personal career but you 
can always look at it from another perspective, she is putting the needs of 
others above their own personal ambition - it takes a strong, unselfish 
person to do that.
It means that men do more work in paying jobs, but the money a man receives 
is not all his if it's a married man, or a man with children - part of it 
belongs to his wife or to finance children. It's more common for a man to 
be working in paying job but it doesn't mean he has more money than his 
wife who is at home because it's their money. Also, a women divorced who 
gets alimony is entitled to part of her ex husband's earnings, but stats 
that only show working and unemployed would show he got all the money 
making huge difference and further creating a myth of wage gap.

I've read a study that women tend to be more critical towards their own 
work and therefor less likely to ask for a raise - this actually goes in 
favor of the original statement that women of equal skill are payed less 
than men, but if you go to your boss with: "Pay me more or I am out" 
attitude you are risking losing your job, so maybe women are being more 
careful, which is consistent with the fact that women take less risks than 
men. It may seem unfair at first but that's how women and men generally are 
different - no one says it's unfair that men tend to lose their lives in 
accidents more because we all know men tend to do more crazy stuff. Nature 
of men to take risks by has some rewards but a huge downside as well.﻿

comments.text:
The Danish dream is real. You know the dream of becoming financially stable 
and being able to afford all necessities, in a nice apartment with a good 
car and not be worried about becoming sick, or losing your job? Here, if 
you work 7,5 hours a day, in a just above minimum wage job (say, educated 
with a company, that kind of job), you'll be able to afford all this for 
yourself. Even if you work minimum wage you'll be able to afford all this, 
the car will just be a bit cheaper. Also, you get free healthcare, free 
education and the least corrupt police force in the world, with only 0.187 
person killed annually by police, pr. 1 million inhabitants, and all uses 
of firearms against civilians, since 1996, wasn't intended to kill. Now 
tell me, where would you rather live, Denmark, or USA?﻿

I wouldn't recommend learning Danish, we all speak perfect or near perfect 
English anyway. But moving to Denmark is sadly quite a hassle, and you'll 
need a job here prior to moving. It's quite easy to get allowance to stay 
here, as an american, but you're probably never get citizenship, which is 
what's needed for the free healthcare, education, pension etc. It takes a 
long time, like 10-20 years to become eligible for citizenship.
We sadly have a government that is illogically afraid of immigrants, even 
though we need people for our workforce. 
A financial crisis will do that to you.

floors, mop the floors, clean the bathrooms...

comments.text:
+James Correia I never said that we should do away with government. 
 Government is a necessary evil for a civilized society.  But taxing an 
individual to run a government is needed and necessary.  However, when 
government applies taxes to ""things"" like Death or the taking of money 
from people who don't earn much to begin with is the crime of government.

For instance.

when a person dies the people inheriting the money may have to a pay a tax. 
 Why, that dollar has already been taxed.  Why should those receiving the 
money be taxed on that money that has already been taxed?

Why should a person making $15,000 a year gross income pay a tax of $500 or 
$700 dollars?  If the objective is to LIFT that person out of poverty is 
the goal than would it not make sense not to tax that individual?

National Parks do you mean like Yellow Stone?  Yellow Stone woods, and open 
grasslands have existed for 100,000 of thousands of years with no 
government involvement. Same is true for the Grand Canyon.  Why do we need 
a parks and recreation department to keep those areas open? Are they not 
already open spaces to enjoy?

Sure we use tax ,money to maintain structures such as the Lincoln, 
Jefferson, Washington homes, monuments.  But did we really need to close 
down the World War II Memorial during the last government shut down?  Whats 
the point, its OUTSIDE anyway.   It continues to be OUTSIDE.

Everyday Government is involved in your life from how much water your 
toilet uses, shower head uses, dishwasher uses.  Government sets standards 
on cars, trucks, power equipment.  Government sets safety requirements. 
 Government tells mattress manufactures, bed sheet makers, blanket 
companies what they can and can not use as material for those products.

I am NOT saying that a mattress, bed sheet, blanket company should  Willie 
Nilly use flammable materials, but its the FREE MARKET that decides that. 
 Example if you could purchase a Comforter for a bed and you knew the 
material inside was highly flammable would you buy it? I would hope not, 
and therefore because people don't buy that product the company goes out of 
business.

YEARS before Ralph Nader, car companies were already designing safety 
features into vehicles because that's what people wanted, safer cars.  Did 
Ralph Nader's involvement speed it up sure it did...but I ask you why can't 
I buy with out seat belts?  Because the Laws in some states require you to 
wear them...requiring said item just jacks up the price of a car...right?

My point is this, we need government but not the nanny state we have today.

comments.text:
+Stephen Wood Capitalists..do you know even what one is?

Definition: a wealthy person who uses money to invest in trade and industry 
for profit in accordance with the principles of capitalism.

Definition of Capitalism: an economic system in which investment in and 
ownership of the means of production, distribution, and exchange of wealth 
is made and maintained chiefly by private individuals or corporations, 
especially as contrasted to cooperatively or state-owned means of wealth.

So with out people who have Capital - definition of Capital: wealth in the 
form of money or other assets owned by a person or organization or 
available or contributed for a particular purpose such as starting a 
company or investing.

You would not have companies like Target, Walmart, JC Penny, Honeywell, 
Boeing, CVS, Walgreens, RiteAid, Staples, Burger King, McDonalds, Wendys, 
... none of this would exist in the form that we see today.

the profits or selling shares of their companies to people who were willing

Liberals believe that companies such as the ones listed above are evil,

These companies provide jobs of all kinds for all kinds of people.  They 
provide products and services...which in turn create jobs for those people 
that create and distribute the services that they sell, and that creates 
WEALTH.  Which in turn creates wealth for the government to pay its bills 
because people have more money. 

Liberals and Democrats and people who feel that corporations are evil money 
making machines ... I have this one question for you....do you work for a 
person or a company that makes zero profit?  I mean if you feel that 
Capitalism, which is really the wrong word for what we have ... its really

comments.author: Kos Mos

comments.text:
+blownspeakersss Besides, say, "opportunities"; which is THE basis of the 
American dream, the notion that one can climb up the social ladder 
regardless of their background. Unfortunately, that is not entirely so with 
women. 
I do agree with you on one point, that a women can achieve her goals 
through hard work (if you are rich, educated, childless, and preferable 
white). There are no set rules to prevent a women from doing that nowadays, 
but we have to take a look at the deeper story to understand why there is a 
gender pay gap and why women are entering lower pay occupations. The story 
isn't as simple "they chose to" 
1.) Exposure
There are not many successful women figures our children can look up to, in 
real-life or in media. Only about 20% of parliament are made up of women 
(The US ranks second to last, only beating Japan), there has been no female 
president in the US history, and even in media a women's measured by her 
looks. What is it telling our children, that there are no powerful women 
who achieved their success through "hard work" AKA the American Dream? It 
would be a lie to say, that these exposures to what an "Ideal women" should 
be, does not affect our children. These are messages deep-rooted into them 
from birth, something that they can't simply "ignore". 
2.) Sexism 
Sexism is hardly ever the only reason to the gender pay gap. Would it not 
sound appealing to you as a CEO, to pay a portion of your workers 20% less, 
for reasons you don't need to justify yourself? Of course, genuine 
workplace sexism does exist. There are many studies that compare salary of 
women and men from the same occupation with the same education, which still 
shows the gender pay gap. Choosing to enter a lower paying job, is a lousy 
excuse to cover up the issue. Really, with a history of male-only workers 
and gender stereotypes, why would the gender pay gap surprise you? 
3.) Social Pressure 
If our wonderful girls in school spend their time chasing the American 
Dream instead of doing makeup and suffering from body image anxiety issues, 
they would be a lot more productive no? But it is not "their choice" to 
suffer from anorexia, it is not "their choice" for feeling the need to be 
sexually appealing to be accepted. Children, like a piece of clay, are 
easily moulded by their environment and society. Like I have stated above, 
they learn from taking in what is shown to them. They can't just disregard 
social pressure, tell a man in the 50s to become a stay-at-home dad while 
his wife supports him and disregard the pressure. (A bit overdramatic, but 
you get my point) 
4.) Childbirth 
As if childbirth should ever be a reason against women, because it is never 
one gender that is responsible for a pregnancy. Even though the American 
society is aging at a lower pace than Japan (but still aging), childbirth 
should never ever ever be the reason 50% of the workforce should be 
penalized. I will go more into the consequences in the next post.
comments.author: Jasmine Chao

scientist (or whatever else).

comments.text:
Research over the last few years has found that incentives can limit or 
impair performance, particularly in situations requiring creativity and 
innovation. This isn't a one-of-a-kind finding either. It has been repeated 
in small and large companies and even in lab settings. That's not to say 
there isn't also evidence that DOES correlate monetary incentive with 
creative performance. Nonetheless, we can no longer make the assumption 
that lessening massive wages will lead to a significant decrease in 
innovation. There are likely more complicated factors at work (namely 
organizational/systematic features, like skill-building and autonomy.)

In addition, a fallacy arises when you compare high taxes to removing 
incentive because it implies a kind of false dichotomy. You are not 
actually removing the incentive when you raise taxes, only lessening it. 
There are clear diminishing returns on the amount of productivity that can 
be inspired by more incentive, and so it's obvious you can only follow that 
less tax, more productivity logic so far up the wage ladder. Gallup surveys 
even revealed that happiness typically stops increasing around $75k/year in 
terms of wage increases. So fighting to protect wealth from taxes, 
especially when you reach that fairly wealthy level, is self-defeating. ﻿

Most studies into the cause of the wage gender gap indicate that only a 
small percentage of that is due to discrimination, and the rest is due to 
how many hours and experience are available to women in different fields.

Remember: correlation doesn't always prove direct causation. The solution 
to this problem is thus not so simple as fighting sexism, and has more to 
do with opportunity itself. Like you always say, John, truth defies 
simplicity.﻿

comments.author: Zachery Iskhakov

comments.text:
You say that women earn 77 cents to every dollar men make, but is this an 
average, or what?
Assuming it is an average, how is this unjust? So what if the average woman 
earns less than the average man? That may just mean that women tend toward 
jobs that happen to pay less than the jobs that more men tend towards. It 
doesn't prove anything about gender inequality. Some demographics just earn 
more money than others. Considering how much more income can change from 
job to job, that small difference between genders seems insignificant.

Even if you split the population by something arbitrary, you can expect a 
difference. Suppose we compared the average earnings of Americans who are 
over 5.5 feet tall with those who are under that height. You can expect 
their earnings to differ, but that doesn't mean the group who earns less is 
the victim of injustice.﻿

comments.author: Sarah Hill

comments.text:
Playing devil's advocate, I'm not sure how good a statistic "Women make 
$0.77 for every $1 that men make" really is. If it is across the entire 
workforce, it doesn't take into account the differences in the jobs that 
men and women work.

If we were to count jobs withing a career field, I believe that much of the 
differences would go away. If we count time in that career, I believe that 
more of the differences would disappear. Equal no; closer than 77 to 100 
probably. 

I am curious as to whether or not this kind of comparison has been made by 
career. I have heard that women do best as a pharmacist than any other 
career field, so maybe it has.

I do believe that women almost always make less than men, but 77 vs 100 is 
too pat a quote to believe that it is that simple.﻿
comments.author: Phil Heaton
